etymologies: late 17th century; earliest use found in William Leybourn (1626–1716). From ancient Greek σκιά shadow + -grapher, after skiagraphy and Hellenistic Greek σκιαγράϕος (later σκιογράϕος, attested in variant readings in the Septuagint) perspective-painter, scene-painter

definitions: A person skilled at making sundials and in the art of dialling.
An artist skilled at using shading to convey perspective.
A person skilled in the use of X-rays; = "radiographer". Now chiefly historical.
